Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 11:22AM silverlady wrote: I want to thank all you ladies, Vegas, LisaMG, and etc.!  I just came back from my Oncologist, Dr Malhotra and was informed that yes, my cancer is Triple Negative.  The Ki-67 was - 25%.  He said it was higher than he would have wanted!  My cancer falls into the 10% to 40% range with makes it moderately fast growing.  Because of this, I will have to have Chemo!  Darn!  Oh well....  I told him everything I have read is that most cancers are slow growing.  I had a Mamo in March, a heart scan in April, all negative and here 4 months later I have a 3 X 2.5 cm cancer???  Doesn't sound very slow growing to me.  He said that my prognosis is good for 10 years if they do not find anything in the nodes.  There was no cancer visable in PET/CT scan, and no swelling  in nodes.  I started this whole thing out feeling quite confident, was told probably 1 cm, and stage 1.  Now it is much larger, est, and prog, negative and more serious!  I still fell that I am going to come through this fine and be around for a long while.  My husband and I had planed a road trip to California to visit family around Nov 11 and come back after Christmas.  He said NO!  If you want to fly back for 1 week, that will be ok...said to make my flight now. haha   My surgery is set for the 10 of Sept and he said Chemo would probably start in a month, depending on how fast I heal.  Don't know how long the Chemo would be, but from things I have read maybe 4 to 6 wks???  Is that about right?  If that is the case, I could still be on Chemo the middle of Nov.  Dr Malhotra thought I would be too tired to do a road trip or to stay longer than a week.  What has been you ladies experience?  I have a good friend who had a modified radical in 1979 and took 6 or 7 lymph nodes, has no swelling of the arm and has been cancer FREE for 30 years!  I want to be like her and hopefully all you ladies also.  God Bless you!

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 07:04AM silverlady wrote: I do not know all the details....I forgot my little black book with all the questions in it when I went to the Dr yesterday.  I know it is stage one and contained.  I am 68, and no cancer in my family.  However, I had a mamo in March and now I find this lump the first of Aug, that feels like the size of the tip of my thumb.  A home health care lady called me yesterday evening, and she said her Mom had a double mastectomy last year. 6 years ago, she had some pre-cancerous spots and took tamoxifen for 5 years, went for her mamo last spring and they found cancer in that breast.  She choose a double mas., and then they found cancer cells in the right breast also after examining it.  I am not the least concerned about having them removed, of course I wish I did not have cancer.  I think I will have a double.  God bless you and may you make a speedy recovery!  Thank you so much for writing.  Congrats to you Mom also!  Whoopee!

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 12:45PM silverlady wrote: Thanks for your reply.  Yes, I knew what kind of cancer I have, and the Estrogen receptor information was taken off the Pathology report.  I do not have estrogen receptors, so will not be a candidate for Tamara, which is the newest drug instead of Tamoxifin.  My Oncologist has discussed this with me and said he would use Tamara if I "had" Estrogen Receptors.  I also saw a Dr speaking on the news the other day suggesting you take Tamara over Tamoxifin.  My sister-in-laws daughter was diagnosed with cancer in one breast 2 years ago, at age 46, and chose to have a bi-lateral mastectomy, cancer was very small but in her nodes.    The size of your cancer can be very small, less than a cm and if it is invasive and gone to your lymph nodes, can be serious.  I notice you have DCIS and LCIS, which are both non-invasive or have not spread past the point of origin, plus the risk with Atypical Hyperplasia is relatively low.  And based on those findings, I too would probably have a lumpectomy, but with your IDC, which is what I have, my choice is to have a bi-lateral.  My Surgeon gives each of his cancer patients, the book; BREAST CANCER FOR DUMMIES, written by Dr's.  Very very informative, will answer all my questions when I have read it all, am half way through.  I am so glad to hear your Mom is doing well and I hope the best for you also.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 04:23PM silverlady wrote: HI...  I found my lump on August 1st, the size of my thumb from the knuckle to the tip.  But with the kind of cancer I have, that does not mean my cancer is that big.  I had a mamo this past March and nothing showed.  And now it is the size of my thumb!  I kind of questions that cancers are slow growng after that.  Went in to my Dr and he set up Mamo and ultra sound and a blood test to make sure it hadn't spread to bones and liver.  Saw my surgeon Wed. following that, and he did another Ultra sound and told me that 8 out 10 it was probably cancer.  I had a core biopsy and he said it was for sure cancer, and he guessed about 1 cm which was good.  The next day his office called and asked me if I had a choice for an oncologist and they set up an appt with him.  From the Oncologists office last Friday, I went to have an MRI  and chest Xray and on this past Monday, I saw my surgeon again, and he said my chest Xray was clear, and the cancer in my breast showed up very clear on the MRI.  He asked me what I wanted to do as I was a candidate for a lumpectomy or mastectomy.  I told him masectomy, but have since changed my mind and want a bi-lateral.  I still do not have the HER-2 tests back.  He said the cancer could be bigger, and once they are in there, they will do test on  2 or three lymph nodes, and if no cancer, they will not take them out.  The book I am reading, BREAST CANCER FOR DUMMIES, says you will not know for sure what stage cancer you have until they see how far it has spread and that will be done during and after surgery.  Yesterday I had a PET scan and Low dose CT scan.  The PET scan shows if there is cancer in other places in your body and the CT scan pinpoints where.  I see my Oncologist this Friday and my surgery is scheduled for the 10th of Sep.  My surgeon also contacted a Home Health Care Service, and she will try to meet me in the hospital before I come home and then a nurse will come to my home after that to change dressings and teach me exercises and answer any questions I may have.   I found my Surgeon when I had visited a dermatologist to have a suspicious mole removed and mentioned the lump in my breast.  He mentioned the Dr Yarrington because he said he had heard great things about him and kept current withy new things.  I mentioned his name to my Primary Care Dr and he agreed.  Thank God, things have really fallen in place for me, I have a very positive attitude and intend to be around to see all my grandkids grow up!  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 09:37AM silverlady wrote: I too was diagnosed the same day as you, so I too am new to all this...but I think, just because your cancer is genetic, IS NOT A DEATH SENTENCE!   I too called my Internist and asked him to refill a prescription for my Tranquilizer.  Please keep a positive attitude and only think that this is something you are going to survive!  When I visited my surgeon the first time, before the biposy, he gave me the book; Breast Cancer for DUMMIES!  This book is written by Dr's and explains all the things you are worrying about.  He says, he gives it to all his cancer patients.  Wow, I was amazed you can't call your surgeon.  I am afraid that is what is going to happen here if the health care reform is passed!  Just remember this, your two sons would much rather have you here with them, no matter for how long.  I think loosing a Mom by suicide would be worse.  God bless you and your boys.
